data.title: Singer Martha Wainwright: My six best albums
data.meta_description: MARTHA WAINWRIGHT, 39, is the singer songwriter daughter of folk artists Loudon Wainwright III and Kate McGarrigle and has released five albums. Her latest, Songs In The Dark, with sister Lucy as the Wainwright Sisters, is out on November 13.
data.text:
THE EVERLY BROTHERS: Songs Our Daddy Taught Us (Ace)

A record that my mother played for me and my brother Rufus. It marked the beginning of my love for country music.

Hearing the two voices blending and moving freely between melody and harmony was a genuine revelation.

LOU REED AND JOHN CALE: Songs For Drella (Warner)

This is dedicated to Andy Warhol and was my first introduction to a concept record. The lyrics really affected me and when Lou Reed died I played it a lot.

PRINCE: Purple Rain (Warner)

Prince’s ability to mix so many genres and his fusing of white and black music is remarkable. He is one of the most intriguing artists ever. This was the soundtrack to my youth.

THE STAPLE SINGERS: City In The Sky (Stax)

This group made gospel music accessible. Normally I wouldn’t listen to music with a message but the album is done in such an artistic way and Mavis Staples’s low voice with that full-on abandon is amazing.

Invalid email

LEONARD COHEN: I’m Your Man (Sony)

As a child I found the lyrics to be really grown up. And when I saw the repartee that Cohen had with his backing singers, I wanted to be one.

Later his daughter said I should have been but by then I was making my own records.

KATE & ANNA McGARRIGLE: Heartbeats Accelerating (Private Music)

This was my mum and aunt’s comeback record in 1990 after bringing up their children. I loved the mood of it and that it’s about becoming middle-aged, which is moving
